The purpose of image augmentation is to create new training samples from the existing data.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eHere is an example of how you can apply some \u003ca href=\"#i-want-to-use-albumentations-for-the-specific-task-such-as-classification-or-segmentation\"\u003esupports all common computer vision tasks\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e such as classification, semantic segmentation, instance segmentation, object detection, and pose estimation.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe library provides \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"#a-simple-example\"\u003ea simple unified API\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e to work with all data types: images (RBG-images, grayscale images, multispectral images), segmentation masks, bounding boxes, and keypoints.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eThe library contains \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"#list-of-augmentations\"\u003emore than 70 different augmentations\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e to generate new training samples from the existing data.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eAlbumentations is \u003ca href=\"#benchmarking-results\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003efast\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e. We benchmark each new release to ensure that augmentations provide maximum speed.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003eIt \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"#i-want-to-know-how-to-use-albumentations-with-deep-learning-frameworks\"\u003eworks with popular deep learning frameworks\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e such as PyTorch and TensorFlow. By the way, Albumentations is a part of the \u003ca href=\"https://pytorch.org/ecosystem/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003ePyTorch ecosystem\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003ca href=\"#authors\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWritten by experts\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e. The authors have experience both working on production computer vision systems and participating in competitive machine learning. data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"import albumentations as A\nimport cv2\n\n# Declare an augmentation pipeline\ntransform = A.Compose([\n    A.RandomCrop(width=256, height=256),\n    A.HorizontalFlip(p=0.5),\n    A.RandomBrightnessContrast(p=0.2),\n])\n\n# Read an image with OpenCV and convert it to the RGB colorspace\nimage = cv2.imread(\u0026quot;image.jpg\u0026quot;)\nimage = cv2.cvtColor(image, cv2.COLOR_BGR2RGB)\n\n# Augment an image\ntransformed = transform(image=image)\ntransformed_image = transformed[\u0026quot;image\u0026quot;]\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan rel="nofollow">Docs</a></p><p dir="auto">Albumentations is a Python library for image augmentation. Image augmentation is used in deep learning and computer vision tasks to increase the quality of trained models. The purpose of image augmentation is to create new training samples from the existing data.</p><p dir="auto">Here is an example of how you can apply some <a href="#pixel-level-transforms">pixel-level</a> augmentations from Albumentations to create new images from the original one:<a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer nofollow" href="https://camo.githubusercontent.com/0a0cea2503f569ac965d9de888206b482d13ffe751c682638c730296a352e1ba/68747470733a2f2f686162726173746f726167652e6f72672f776562742f62642f6e652f72762f62646e6572763563746b75646d73617a6e687734637273646669772e6a706567"><img class="heading-element" dir="auto">Why Albumentations</h2><a id="user-content-why-albumentations" class="anchor-element" aria-label="Permalink: Why Albumentations" href="#why-albumentations"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div><ul dir="auto"><li>Albumentations <strong><a href="#i-want-to-use-albumentations-for-the-specific-task-such-as-classification-or-segmentation">supports all common computer vision tasks</a></strong> such as classification, semantic segmentation, instance segmentation, object detection, and pose estimation.</li><li>The library provides <strong><a href="#a-simple-example">a simple unified API</a></strong> to work with all data types: images (RBG-images, grayscale images, multispectral images), segmentation masks, bounding boxes, and keypoints.</li><li>The library contains <strong><a href="#list-of-augmentations">more than 70 different augmentations</a></strong> to generate new training samples from the existing data.</li><li>Albumentations is <a href="#benchmarking-results"><strong>fast</strong></a>. We benchmark each new release to ensure that augmentations provide maximum speed.</li><li>It <strong><a href="#i-want-to-know-how-to-use-albumentations-with-deep-learning-frameworks">works with popular deep learning frameworks</a></strong> such as PyTorch and TensorFlow. By the way, Albumentations is a part of the <a href="https://pytorch.org/ecosystem/" rel="nofollow">PyTorch ecosystem</a>.</li><li><a href="#authors"><strong>Written by experts</strong></a>. The authors have experience both working on production computer vision systems and participating in competitive machine learning. Many core team members are Kaggle Masters and Grandmasters.</li><li>The library is <a href="#who-is-using-albumentations"><strong>widely used</strong></a> in industry, deep learning research, machine learning competitions, and open source projects.</li></ul><div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Table of contents</h2><a
